Blondell also had a brother, Ed Blondell, Jr. Her cradle was a property trunk as her parents moved from place to place and she made her first appearance on stage at the age of four months when she was carried on in a cradle as the daughter of Peggy Astaire in ''The Greatest Love''. Her family comprised a vaudeville troupe, the "Bouncing Blondells".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rathbun|first1=Joe|title=Joe's Radio Parade|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2332732/blondells_in_vaudeville/|agency=Sunday Times Signal|date=December 10, 1944|page=23|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate=May 1, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504122114/http://www.newspapers.com/clip/2332732/blondells_in_vaudeville/|archivedate=May 4, 2015|df=}} {{Open access}}</ref>
Joan had spent a year in Honolulu (1914–15) <ref>[[Punahou School]] Alumni Directory, 1841-1991. White Plains, NY: Harris Publishing Company, 1991.</ref> and six years in Australia and had seen much of the world by the time her family, who had been on tour, settled in [[Dallas, Texas]], when she was a teenager. Under the name Rosebud Blondell, she won the 1926 Miss Dallas [[Beauty contest|pageant]], was a finalist in an early version of the Miss Universe pageant in May 1926, and placed fourth for [[Miss America 1926]] in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]], in September of that same year. She attended [[Santa Monica High School]], where she acted in school plays and worked as an editor on the yearbook staff.<ref>Santa Monica High School Yearbook 1925</ref> While there, she went by the name Rosebud Blondell. She attended what is now the [[University of North Texas]], then a teacher's college, in [[Denton, Texas|Denton]], where her mother was a local stage actress.
==Career== [[File:Joan Blondell in Three on a Match trailer.jpg|left|thumb|Blondell in the trailer for the 1932 film ''[[Three on a Match]]'']]
Around 1927, she returned to New York, worked as a fashion [[Model (person)|model]], a circus hand, a clerk in a store, joined a stock company to become an actress, and performed on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. In 1930, she starred with [[James Cagney]] in ''Penny Arcade'' on Broadway.<ref>{{IBDB name|32322}}</ref> ''Penny Arcade'' lasted only three weeks, but [[Al Jolson]] saw it and bought the rights to the play for $20,000. He then sold the rights to [[Warner Bros.]] with the proviso that Blondell and Cagney be cast in the film version. Placed under contract by Warner Bros., she moved to Hollywood, where studio boss [[Jack L. Warner]] wanted her to change her name to "Inez Holmes",<ref>{{cite book |last=Kennedy|first=Matthew|date= 2007|title=Joan Blondell, a life between takes|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|page=34}}</ref> but Blondell refused. She began to appear in short subjects, and was named as one of the [[WAMPAS Baby Stars]] in 1931.
Blondell was paired with James Cagney in such films as ''[[Sinners' Holiday]]'' (1930) – the film version of ''Penny Arcade'' – and ''[[The Public Enemy]]'' (1931), and was one-half of a gold-digging duo with Glenda Farrell in nine films. During the [[Great Depression]], Blondell was one of the highest-paid individuals in the United States. Her stirring rendition of "Remember My Forgotten Man" in the [[Busby Berkeley]] production of ''[[Gold Diggers of 1933]]'', in which she co-starred with [[Dick Powell]] and [[Ruby Keeler]], became an anthem for the frustrations of the unemployed and the government's failed economic policies. In 1937, she starred opposite [[Errol Flynn]] in ''[[The Perfect Specimen]]''. By the end of the decade, she had made nearly 50 films. She left Warner Bros. in 1939. [[File:Joan Blondell banned 1932 publicity photo.jpg|thumb|This 1932 promotional photo of Blondell was later banned under the [[Motion Picture Production Code]].]]
In 1943, Blondell returned to Broadway as the star of Mike Todd's short-lived production of ''The Naked Genius'', a comedy written by [[Gypsy Rose Lee]].<ref name="NYT Obit"/> She was well received in her later films, despite being relegated to character and supporting roles after 1945, when she was billed below the title for the first time in 14 years in ''[[Adventure (1945 film)|Adventure]]'', which starred [[Clark Gable]] and [[Greer Garson]]. She was also featured prominently in ''[[A Tree Grows in Brooklyn (1945 film)|A Tree Grows in Brooklyn]]'' (1945) and ''[[Nightmare Alley (1947 film)|Nightmare Alley]]'' (1947). In 1948, she left the screen for three years and concentrated on theatre, performing in summer stock and touring with [[Cole Porter]]'s musical, ''[[Something for the Boys]]''.<ref name="NYT Obit"/> She later reprised her role of Aunt Sissy in the musical version of ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn'' for the national tour, starred opposite [[Tallulah Bankhead]] in the play ''[[Crazy October]]'' (which closed on the road) and played the nagging mother, Mae Peterson, in the national tour of ''[[Bye Bye Birdie]]''.
Blondell returned to Hollywood in 1950. Her performance in her next film, ''[[The Blue Veil (1951 film)|The Blue Veil]]'' (1951), earned her an [[24th Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Actress in a Supporting Role]].<ref name="NYT Obit"/> She played supporting roles in ''[[The Opposite Sex]]'' (1956), ''[[Desk Set]]'' (1957), and ''[[Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?]]'' (1957). She received considerable acclaim for her performance as Lady Fingers in [[Norman Jewison]]'s ''[[The Cincinnati Kid]]'' (1965), garnering a [[Golden Globe]] nomination and [[National Board of Review]] win for Best Supporting Actress. [[John Cassavetes]] cast her as a cynical, aging playwright in his film ''[[Opening Night (1977 film)|Opening Night]]'' (1977). Blondell was widely seen in two films released not long before her death, ''[[Grease (film)|Grease]]'' (1978) and the remake of ''[[The Champ (1979 film)|The Champ]]'' (1979) with [[Jon Voight]] and [[Rick Schroder]]. She also appeared in two films released after her death, ''[[The Glove (film)|The Glove]]'' (1979) and ''[[The Woman Inside]]'' (1981).
[[File:James Cagney and Joan Blondell in Footlight Parade trailer.jpg|left|thumb|With [[James Cagney]] in ''[[Footlight Parade]]'' (1933)]] Blondell also guest-starred in various television programs, including three 1963 episodes as the character Aunt Win in the [[CBS]] sitcom ''[[The Real McCoys]]'', starring [[Walter Brennan]] and [[Richard Crenna]]. She appeared in a 1964 episode ("What's in the Box?") of ''[[The Twilight Zone]]''. She guest-starred in the episode "You're All Right, Ivy" of [[Jack Palance]]'s circus drama, ''[[The Greatest Show on Earth (TV series)|The Greatest Show on Earth]]'', which aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] in the 1963–64 television season. Her co-stars in the segment were [[Joe E. Brown (comedian)|Joe E. Brown]] and [[Buster Keaton]]. In 1965, she was in the running to replace [[Vivian Vance]] as Lucille Ball's sidekick on the hit CBS television comedy series ''[[The Lucy Show]]''. Unfortunately, after filming her second guest appearance as Joan Brenner (Lucy's new friend from California), Blondell walked off the set right after the episode had completed filming when Ball humiliated her by harshly criticizing her performance in front of the studio audience and technicians.
Blondell continued working on television. In 1968, she guest-starred on the CBS sitcom ''[[Family Affair]]'', starring [[Brian Keith]]. She also replaced [[Bea Benaderet]], who was ill, for one episode on the CBS series ''[[Petticoat Junction]]''. In that installment, Blondell played FloraBelle Campbell, a lady visitor to [[Hooterville]], who had once dated Uncle Joe ([[Edgar Buchanan]]) and Sam Drucker ([[Frank Cady]]). That same year, Blondell co-starred in all 52 episodes of the ABC [[Western (genre)|Western]] series ''[[Here Come the Brides]]'', set in the [[Pacific Northwest]] of the 19th century. Her co-stars included singer [[Bobby Sherman]] and actor-singer [[David Soul]]. Blondell received two consecutive Emmy nominations for outstanding continued performance by an actress in a dramatic series for her role as Lottie Hatfield.
In 1971, she followed [[Sada Thompson]] in the off-Broadway hit ''[[The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds]]'', with a young [[Swoosie Kurtz]] playing one of daughters.<ref>http://www.lortel.org/Archives/CreditableEntity/23741</ref> [[File:John Wayne - Joan Blondell - 1942.jpg|thumb|[[John Wayne]] and Blondell, in ''[[Lady for a Night]]'' (1942)]] In 1972, she had an ongoing supporting role in the NBC series ''[[Banyon]]'' as Peggy Revere, who operated a secretarial school in the same building as Banyon's detective agency. This was a 1930s period action drama starring [[Robert Forster]] in the titular role. Her students worked in Banyon's office, providing fresh faces for the show weekly. The series was replaced midseason.
In 1974, Blondell played the wife of [[Tom D'Andrea]]'s character in the television film, ''Bobby Parker and Company'', with [[Ted Bessell]] in the starring role as the son of Blondell and D'Andrea. Coincidentally, D'Andrea had earlier played Jim Gillis, the television husband of Blondell's younger sister, [[Gloria Blondell]], in the NBC sitcom ''[[The Life of Riley]]''.
Blondell has a [[List of actors with Hollywood Walk of Fame motion picture stars|motion pictures star]] on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] for her contributions to the film industry. Her star is located at 6311 [[Hollywood Boulevard]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.walkoffame.com/joan-blondell |title=Hollywood Walk of Fame - Joan Blondell |website=walkoffame.com |publisher=Hollywood Chamber of Commerce |accessdate=November 21, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201050654/http://www.walkoffame.com/joan-blondell |archivedate=December 1, 2017 |df= }}</ref> In December 2007, the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York City mounted a retrospective of Blondell's films in connection with a new biography by film professor [[Matthew Kennedy (author)|Matthew Kennedy]] and theatrical revival houses such as [[Film Forum]] in [[Manhattan]] have also projected many of her films recently.
She wrote a novel titled ''Center Door Fancy'' (New York: [[Delacorte Press]], 1972), which was a thinly disguised autobiography with veiled references to June Allyson and Dick Powell.<ref>{{cite book |last=Kennedy|first=Matthew|date= 2007|title=Joan Blondell, a life between takes|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|page=10}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:Joan-Blondell-Children-1944.jpg|left|thumb|Joan Blondell, with daughter Ellen Powell and son [[Norman Powell (television executive)|Norman S. Powell]] (1944)]] Blondell was married three times, first to [[cinematographer]] [[George Barnes (cinematographer)|George Barnes]] in a private wedding ceremony on January 4, 1933, at the First Presbyterian Church in [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. They had one child — [[Norman Powell (television executive)|Norman Scott Barnes]], who became an accomplished producer, director, and television executive — and divorced in 1936.
On September 19, 1936, she married her second husband, actor, [[film director|director]], and singer [[Dick Powell]]. They had a daughter, Ellen Powell, who became a studio hair stylist, and Powell adopted her son by her previous marriage under the name Norman Scott Powell. Blondell and Powell were divorced on July 14, 1944. Blondell was less than friendly with Powell's next wife, [[June Allyson]], although the two women would later appear together in ''[[The Opposite Sex]]'' (1956).
[[File:Joan Blondell Grave.JPG|thumb|Niche of Joan Blondell at Forest Lawn Glendale.]] On July 5, 1947, Blondell married her third husband, [[Film producer|producer]] [[Mike Todd]], whom she divorced in 1950. Her marriage to Todd was an emotional and financial disaster. She once accused him of holding her outside a hotel window by her ankles.<ref>{{cite web | first=Matthew | last=Kennedy | title=Joan Blondell: A Life Between Takes | publisher=University Press of Mississippi | year=1993| isbn=9781628461817}}</ref> He was also a heavy spender who lost hundreds of thousands of dollars gambling (high-stakes [[contract bridge|bridge]] was one of his weaknesses) and went through a controversial [[bankruptcy]] during their marriage. An often-repeated myth is that Mike Todd "dumped" Joan Blondell for [[Elizabeth Taylor]], when in fact, Blondell left Todd of her own accord years before he met Taylor.
Blondell was a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QfHXAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA173#v=onepage&q=Joan+Blondell | title=When Hollywood Was Right: How Movie Stars, Studio Moguls, and Big Business Remade American Politics | first=Donald T. | last=Critchlow | date=21 October 2013 | publisher=Cambridge University Press | accessdate=5 May 2018 | via=Google Books}}</ref>
==Death== Blondell died of [[leukemia]] in [[Santa Monica, California]], on Christmas Day, 1979, with her children and her sister at her bedside.<ref name="NYT Obit"/> She is interred in the [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Glendale, California]].<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FOHgDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69#v=onepage&q=Joan%20Blondell%20burial%20site%20scott%20wilson | title=Resting Places: The Burial Sites of More Than 14,000 Famous Persons | first=Scott | last=Wilson | edition=3rd | publisher=McFarland & Company, Inc. | location=Jefferson, North Carolina | year=2016 | isbn=978-0-7864-7992-4 | page=69 | accessdate=August 2, 2018}}</ref>

[[Limited liability company]] | genre = | traded_as = | company_slogan = | foundation = {{Start date|2014|2|3}} | founder = Jonathan Katz | location_city = [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | location_country = [[United States]] | area_served = | key_people = Jonathan Katz (president/[[chief executive officer|CEO]])
Jeffrey Wolf (chief distribution officer) | industry = [[Media company|Media]] | products = [[Television network]]s | services = | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = 130 (2017) | parent = [[E. W. Scripps Company]] | divisions = | subsid = {{ubl|[[Bounce TV|Bounce Media, LLC]]|[[Escape (TV network)|Escape Media, LLC]]|[[Grit (TV network)|Grit Media, LLC]]|[[Laff (TV network)|Laff Media, LLC]]}} | homepage = {{URL|scripps.com/katz-networks}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Katz Broadcasting, LLC''', is an [[United States|American]] specialized [[digital subchannel|digital multicasting]] network [[media company]] and a subsidiary of [[E. W. Scripps Company]]. The company owns (as of 2017) four [[television network]]s that each carry programming with specified formats targeted at individual demographics. Originally, Katz sold the network to affiliated TV stations via ad split, but by October 2015, had moved to carriage fees in exchange for the network getting the ad inventory due to greater inventory with stations adding a third or fourth subchannel.{{cite news|last1=Jessell|first1=Harry A.|title=OTA The Bedrock of Katz's Growing Diginets |url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/89135/ota-the-bedrock-of-katzs-growing-diginets/page/1|accessdate=October 15, 2015|work=TVNewsCheck|date=October 13, 2015}}:1 Their networks used direct response advertising as a meter of viewers before switching to [[Nielsen ratings#Commercial ratings|Neilsen rating C-3]].:3 ==History== Katz Broadcasting, LLC was founded on February 3, 2014{{cite web|title=Katz Broadcasting, LLC Control Number: 14012024|url=https://cgov.sos.state.ga.us/Account.aspx/ViewEntityData?entityId=4828497|website=state.ga.us|publisher=Georgia Secretary of State|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} by Jonathan Katz, who serves as [[chief operating officer]] of [[Bounce TV]] and formerly served as an executive at the [[Turner Broadcasting System]]. The company was announced concurrently with the announced launches of its first two networks, [[Escape (TV network)|Escape]] and [[Grit (TV network)|Grit]], which were both launched that April with [[Univision]] and [[UniMás]] [[owned-and-operated station]]s run by [[Univision Communications]] serving as its charter station group; both of Katz's initial networks are targeted at individual [[gender]]s (with Grit aimed at men and Escape aimed at women). Besides Jonathan Katz, some of the initial investors included some Bounce investors notably [[Raycom Media]] and Al Haymon. At some point, [[E. W. Scripps Company]] also becomes an owner purchasing 5% of the company. Katz and [[Bounce TV|Bounce Media]] share staff from the former company's launch, including Jonathan Katz (who serves as president and [[chief executive officer]] of Katz, while continuing to serve as [[chief operating officer]]) and Jeffrey Wolf (Katz's chief distribution officer and Bounce's [[executive vice president]] of network distribution).{{cite news|title=Exclusive: Bounce TV Exec Plans Two New Channels |url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/currency/exclusive-bounce-tv-exec-plans-two-new-channels/130235|author=Jon Lafayette |periodical=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |publisher=[[NewBay Media]]|date=April 3, 2014|accessdate=January 28, 2015}}{{cite news|title=Longtime PR Executive Joins Katz Broadcasting, Bounce Network|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/longtime-pr-executive-joins-katz-724020|author=Kaitlyn Durocher|periodical=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media|Guggenheim Digital Media]]|date=August 7, 2014|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} Katz and Bounce continued to share executive staff with the hiring announcement of Jim Weiss (a former executive at sports marketing agency CSE) as the former's senior vice president of corporate communications in August. On January 18, 2015, Katz Broadcasting announced the launch of its third specialty network, [[Laff (TV network)|Laff]], a comedy-focused network that was tapped for an April 15 debut with [[ABC Owned Television Stations]] and the [[E. W. Scripps Company]] serving as its core charter affiliate groups.{{cite news|title=Exclusive: Comedy Multicast Net Launching on ABC, Scripps|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/currency/exclusive-comedy-multicast-net-launching-abc-scripps/137199|author=Jon Lafayette|periodical=Broadcasting & Cable|publisher=NewBay Media|date=January 18, 2015|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} On March 24, 2015, Katz signed a multi-network agreement with the [[Meredith Corporation]] that would add all three Katz-owned networks to Meredith-owned stations in five markets, boosting Laff's national coverage to 50%, Escape's to 58%, and Grit's to 78% of all U.S. television markets.{{cite news|title=Meredith To Carry Grit, Escape, LAFF Networks|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/programming/meredith-carry-grit-escape-laff-networks/138986|author=Jon Lafayette|periodical=Broadcasting & Cable|publisher=NewBay Media|date=March 20, 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2015}} Escape and Grit switched from direct response advertising as a meter of viewers to [[Nielsen ratings#Commercial ratings|Neilsen rating C-3]] late 2015 with Laff expected to follow suit.:3 On June 15, 2016, Katz Broadcasting signed a multi-network agreement with [[Nexstar Media Group|Nexstar Broadcasting Group]] and operated affiliated TV station companies that would bring all three Katz-owned networks (as well as Bounce TV) to stations owned and/or operated by Nexstar in 54 markets, jumping national coverage of both Escape and Laff to 85% and Grit's coverage to 93%.{{cite news|title=Bounce TV, Grit, Escape, Laff Multicast Deal Covers 81 Stations, 54 Markets|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/currency/bounce-tv-grit-escape-laff-multicast-deal-covers-81-stations-54-markets/157330|author=Jon Lafayette|periodical=Broadcasting & Cable|publisher=NewBay Media|date=June 15, 2016|accessdate=June 20, 2016}} On August 1, 2017, E.W. Scripps announced the purchase of Katz and its three networks plus [[Bounce TV|Bounce]] which Katz operates, for $292 million, acquiring the other 95% of the company. Katz will remain based out of [[Atlanta, Georgia]] as an autonomous division of Scripps.{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/local-tv/ew-scripps-buys-katz-networks-302m-deal/167592|title=E.W. Scripps Buys Katz Networks in $302M Deal |last=Marszalek|first=Diana|date=August 1, 2017|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|accessdate=August 2, 2017}} The purchase was completed on October 2, 2017.{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Mark K.|title=E.W. Scripps Closes $302M Katz Purchase|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/107767/ew-scripps-closes-302m-katz-purchase|accessdate=November 7, 2017|work=TVNewsCheck.com|date=October 2, 2017|language=en}} ==Major assets== ===Television networks=== * [[Bounce TV]] (Bounce Media, LLC) A digital broadcast network which specializes in programming for the black community. * [[Escape (TV network)|Escape]] (Escape Media, LLC) A digital broadcast network which specializes in programming for women, featuring series and films focusing on mystery and true crime stories. * [[Grit (TV network)|Grit]] (Grit Media, LLC) A digital broadcast network which specializes in programming for men, featuring mainly action, western, and crime drama films. * [[Laff (TV network)|Laff]] (Laff Media, LLC) A digital broadcast network specializing in comedic series and feature films. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|scripps.com/katz-networks}} {{EWS CORP}} {{Broadcast Television}} {{North American DTV}} [[Category:Companies based in Atlanta]] [[Category:American companies established in 2014]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of the United States]] [[Category:Media companies of the United States]] [[Category:2014 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:The E.W. Fapp]] | editing = [[Alma Macrorie]] | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{start date|1954|4|14}} | runtime = 103 minutes | country = United States | language = English | gross = $3.5 million (US)'The Top Box-Office Hits of 1954', ''Variety Weekly'', January 5, 1955 }} '''''Knock on Wood''''' is a 1954 comedy starring [[Danny Kaye]] and [[Mai Zetterling]]. Other actors in the film include [[Torin Thatcher]], [[David Burns (actor)|David Burns]], and [[Leon Askin]]. The film was written and directed by [[Melvin Frank]] and [[Norman Panama]], with songs by Kaye's wife, [[Sylvia Fine]]. ==Plot== Jerry Morgan (Kaye) is a [[Ventriloquism|ventriloquist]] who is having trouble with love: just when his relationship with a woman gets around to marriage, his dummy turns jealous and spoils everything. Jerry's manager Marty threatens to quit unless Jerry sees a psychiatrist, Ilse Nordstrom (Zetterling), who tries to discover the source of his problem. The two of them eventually fall in love. At the same time, Jerry becomes unwittingly intertwined with spies and has to run from the police. In his escape, he finds himself impersonating a British car salesman, trying to demonstrate a new convertible with loads of bells and whistles. Later on, he finds himself on stage in the middle of the performance of an exotic ballet. ==Cast== * [[Danny Kaye]] as Jerry Morgan/Jerry's father * [[Mai Zetterling]] as Doctor Ilse Nordstrom * [[Torin Thatcher]] as Godfrey Langston, the film's villain * [[David Burns (actor)|David Burns]] as Marty Brown, Jerry's manager * [[Leon Askin]] as Lazlo Gromek, a spy * [[Abner Biberman]] as Maurice Papinek, a spy * Otto Waldis as Brodnik, a spy * [[Gavin Gordon (actor)|Gavin Gordon]] as Car Salesman * [[Steven Geray]] as Doctor Krüger * [[Diana Adams]] as Princess Maya * Patricia Denise as Jerry's Mother * [[Virginia Huston]] as Audrey Greene * Paul England as Chief Inspector Wilton * Johnstone White as Langstons Secretary * [[Henry Brandon (actor)|Henry Brandon]] as Man with a Trenchcoat * [[Lewis Martin (Actor)|Lewis Martin]] as Inspector Crawford ==Production notes== The film features dialogue with linguistic play (particularly the names of the dummies "Clarence" and "Terrence" and the [[Slavic languages|Slavic]] names of the spies) which would also be a feature of Kaye's later film ''[[The Court Jester]]'' (likewise written and directed by Frank and Panama). The title song "Knock on Wood" should not be confused with "Everybody Thinks I'm Crazy" from the 1941 cartoon entitled ''Woody Woodpecker'', starring [[Woody Woodpecker|the character of the same name]]; or the song "Knock on Wood" from the 1942 film, ''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'' (with music by M.K. Jerome and lyrics by Jack Scholl). Kaye performed renditions of both the title song from ''Knock on Wood'' and "The Woody Woodpecker Song," which are found on the album ''The Best of Danny Kaye'' [Spectrum, 2000]. ==DVD release== ''Knock on Wood'' was issued as a region 2 DVD in March 2009. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{imdb title|0047152|Knock on Wood}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|knock-on-wood}} * {{Amg movie|97932|Knock on Wood}} {{Melvin Frank}} {{Norman Panama}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Knock On Wood}} [[Category:1954 films]] [[Category:1950s comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American comedy films]] [[Category:Cold War spy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about psychiatry]] [[Category:Films directed by Norman Panama]] [[Category:Films directed by Melvin Frank]] [[Category:Paramount Pictures films]] [[Category:Spy comedy films]] [[Category:Ventriloquism]] [[Category:Films shot in Los Angeles]]

page.title: List of drive-in theatres in Australia

revision.text:
[[Drive-in theater|Drive-in theatres]] (also known as ''drive-in cinemas'' or ''drive-ins'') were once very popular in [[Australia]]. Although considered{{By whom|date=December 2015}} an American invention there is evidence of outdoor cinemas in Western Australia where some patrons attended in their cars as far back as 1938, and it is possible that these facilities may even predate the first American-style drive-in theatre.<ref name="Drive-in WA">{{Cite web |url=http://www.latrobe.edu.au/screeningthepast/19/drive-ins-WA.html |title=Bringing family life into the theatres |publisher=[[La Trobe University]]|last=Bertrand|first=Ina|date=13 March 2006 |accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref>
==History== The first American-style drive-in theatre to open in Australia was the Skyline in the [[Melbourne]] suburb of [[Burwood, Victoria|Burwood]] on 18 February 1954.<ref name="Burwood">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/vic_burwood.htm |title=Burwood Skyline (Hoyts) |publisher=Drive-ins downunder |year=1999 |accessdate=14 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080721194502/http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/vic_burwood.htm |archivedate=21 July 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Drive-in History">{{Cite web|url=http://www.theatres.com.au/drive-in-theatres/ |title=Drive-in Theatres |publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|work=Australian Theatres Directory|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> It was the first of 330 drive-in theatres that would open across Australia.<ref name="Drive-in History"/>
Many have since closed with the large amounts of land taken up by drive-ins being sold off to build houses or shopping centres, although in recent years a number of drive-in theatres have reopened or expanded the number of screens available.
In the 1990s, the [[Coburg, Victoria|Coburg]] Drive-in Theatre in Melbourne was expanded to three screens,<ref name="Coburg">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/vic_coburg.htm|title=Coburg Triple Drive-in|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> as was the [[Dromana, Victoria|Dromana]] Drive-in Theatre.<ref name="Dromana">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/vic_dromana.htm|title=Dromana Twin/Peninsula|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> In more recent times the former [[Dandenong]] Panoramic Drive-in, in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], has been reopened as the Lunar Drive-in Theatre<ref name="Dandenong">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/vic_dandenong.htm|title=Dandenong Lunar (Panoramic)|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> and now has four screens making it Australia's largest drive-in theatre with the most screen choice.
In 2002 the Rodeo Drive-in at [[Mareeba, Queensland|Mareeba]], near [[Cairns, Queensland|Cairns]], re-opened, with the Tivoli Drive-in near [[Ipswich, Queensland|Ipswich]] re-opening in 2008.
[[File:Drive-in theatre.jpg|thumb|250px|Mainline Drive-in Theatre Gepps Cross South Australia 16 April 2006]]The longest running Drive In Theatres in Western Australia that is still open today is located in [[Dongara, Western Australia|Dongara]]. This opened in 1967 and still operates every summer, the projector has been upgraded to digital to show the latest movies.[[Image:Dandenongpic30.JPG|thumb|250px|Lunar Drive-in Theatre Dandenong Victoria Australia]] [[Image:Bass Hill Drive-in Cinema.JPG|thumb|250px|[[Bass Hill, New South Wales|Bass Hill]] Drive-In Cinema]]
Along with a few metropolitan operations, there are a number of drive-in theatres serving remote communities such as [[Jericho, Queensland|Jericho]] in Queensland.
==By state== The remaining drive-ins provide a glimpse of what was a very popular pastime in the 1950s and 1960s. The following is a listing of Australia's remaining open drive-in theatres. It includes portable operations in which patrons can either drive or sit down to see a movie outdoors.
===Victoria=== Following a visit to the [[United States]] in the early 1950s, [[Hoyts]]' southern division manager, George Griffith Jnr, believed that drive-in theatres would be successful in Australia.<ref name="Burwood"/><ref name="VHDb">{{Cite web|url=http://vhd.heritage.vic.gov.au/search/nattrust_result_detail/71756 |title=Burwood Drive-In Site|publisher=[[Heritage Council of Victoria]]|work=Victorian Heritage Database|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="BB">{{Cite web|url=http://www.babyboomercentral.com.au/icons_driveins.htm|title=Icons: Drive-In Theatres|work=Baby Boomer Central|publisher=Australia On CD|last=Yarrow|first=Stephen|year=2010|accessdate=14 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110223234709/http://www.babyboomercentral.com.au/icons_driveins.htm|archivedate=23 February 2011|df=}}</ref> Hoyts and Fox however did not share Griffith's enthusiasm for the establishment of a drive-in theatre, so Griffith subsequently formed a syndicate, Auto Theatres Pty Ltd,<ref name="Burwood"/> which decided on a site in the Melbourne suburb of Burwood for Australia's first drive-in theatre. Construction proceeded through the latter half of 1953 from plans drawn up by AC Leith Bartlett & Partners in conjunction with RCA Australia.<ref name="VHDb"/><ref name="BB"/> The Skyline Burwood officially opened on 18 February 1954<ref name="Drive-in History"/> and proved extremely popular, with traffic jams in both directions along the Burwood Highway.<ref name="BB"/> Hoyts subsequently bought out Griffith and his partners.<ref name="Burwood"/>
Following the success of the first drive-in theatre, the Skyline (Burwood), Hoyts quickly opened Skyline drive-in theatres at [[Preston, Victoria|Preston]] in 1954,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/vic_prestonhoyts.htm|title=Preston Skyline/Hoyts|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> and [[Oakleigh, Victoria|Oakleigh]] in March 1955.<ref name="Oakleigh">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/vic_oakleigh.htm|title=Oakleigh Skyline/Hoyts|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> The next Hoyts drive-in was constructed in Broadmeadows (1958),<ref name="Broadmeadows">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/vic_broadmeadows.htm|title=Broadmeadows Skyline (Hoyts)|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> but then there was a break of almost 10 years until Hoyts acquired drive-ins at [[Coburg, Victoria|Coburg]] and Oakleigh and constructed new drive-ins in [[Bulleen, Victoria|Bulleen]] (1965), [[Wantirna, Victoria|Wantirna]] (1968) and [[Altona, Victoria|Altona]]. In 1972 the Broadmeadows Skyline was the first of the Melbourne suburban drive-ins to close,<ref name="Broadmeadows"/> whilst the Oakleigh site was the last drive-in operated by Hoyts in the world, when it closed in 1990.<ref name="Oakleigh"/>
Sandringham drive-in theatre (now closed) was located between Tulip and Talinga Roads in Sandringham Victoria. With the entrance being on Tulip St.
Today Melburnians have 10 screens in their immediate vicinity to choose from (counting Dromana as being basically suburban Melbourne). Rural Victorians however have no drive-in theatres currently in operation. * Lunar Drive-in Theatre (four screens), [[Dandenong, Victoria|Dandenong]] :The Lunar Dandenong is now Australia's largest and oldest (still in operation) drive-in theatre.<ref name="Dandenong"/> It was first opened 4 May 1956 and was constructed by J and K Houlahan from plans drawn up by Baily and Tilley.<ref name="Dandenong"/> The original capacity was to be for 400 cars however this was redesigned to accommodate 600 cars, with the final capacity being 634 cars. The drive-in closed on 18 April 1984 and was subsequently purchased by Trash and Treasure Australia Pty Ltd, who operated a Sunday market on the site in the 1970s.<ref name="Dandenong"/> On 19 September 2002 it reopened as a two-screen drive-in, with a third screen added in September 2003 with a 950-car capacity.<ref name="Dandenong"/> * [[Village Cinemas|Village]] Coburg Drive-in (3 Screens), [[Coburg, Victoria|Coburg]] :Coburg opened in November 1965, under the ownership of Sillman and Sharp.<ref name="Coburg"/> It was acquired by [[Hoyts]] in 1967 until it closed in 1984.<ref name="Coburg"/> Hoyts were unable to sell the site despite numerous attempts and in 1987 [[Village Cinemas|Village]] joined with [[Hoyts]] and re-opened Coburg as a twin screen in 1987.<ref name="Coburg"/> A third screen was added in 1995. Coburg was Australia's largest drive-in theatre with an 850 car capacity,<ref name="Coburg"/> until the expansion at Dandenong in 2003. * Dromana 3 Drive-in (3 Screens), [[Dromana, Victoria|Dromana]] :The Dromana was opened in 1961 with a capacity of 485 cars.<ref name="Dromana"/> It has since been expanded to a three screen operation and has a Sunday market operating from the site. It is only one of three that have never closed (since the 1960s), operating continuously since its inception (1961) to the present.<ref>.http://www.nattrust.com.au/trust_register/search_the_register/dromana_drive_in</ref>
===New South Wales=== The Skyline Drive-ins at Frenchs Forest and Dundas were Sydney's first. They opened simultaneously on Wednesday 24 October 1956, with Frenchs Forest screening [[3 Ring Circus]] and Dundas screening [[The Racers]]. <!--- Note: Recent false allegations of the historical existence of a Drive-in theatre in Quakers Hill have been raised by a passionate local with no evidence to back up the claim. There has never been a Drive-in within the vicinity of Quakers Hill....ever.--->
The Skyline in [[Bass Hill, New South Wales|Bass Hill]] opened in November 1956, with a 724 car capacity and until its closure in September 2007 was Australia's oldest continually operating drive-in theatre.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw-act/rescue-bid-for-oldest-drive-in/story-e6freuzi-1111114734830|title=Rescue bid for oldest drive-in |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|last=Williams|first=Lauren|date=27 October 2007|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="Bass Hill">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/nsw_basshill.htm|title=Bass Hill Skyline|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref> This was followed by a Skyline in [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] in December 1956 at a cost of $200,000, with a capacity for 722 cars and a holding area for a further 420.<ref name="Newcastle Herald">{{Cite news|url=http://www.driveintheatres.com.au/drive-in-theatres-articles/1999/9/28/first-place-in-nsw-to-open-a-drivein/|title=First place in NSW to open a Drive-in|publisher=[[Newcastle Herald]]|date=28 September 1999|accessdate=18 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706103542/http://www.driveintheatres.com.au/drive-in-theatres-articles/1999/9/28/first-place-in-nsw-to-open-a-drivein/|archivedate=6 July 2011|df=}}</ref> The Newcastle Skyline closed in June 1985.<ref name="Newcastle Herald"/> The North Ryde Skyline, on Lane Cove Road, accommodated 620 cars and operated for 30 years from 1956.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hogben|first1=Paul|title=Leisure Space: The Transformation of Sydney 1945-1970|publisher=UNSW Press|isbn=9781742246802|pages=152–155}}<!--|accessdate=20 October 2015--></ref><ref>{{cite web|title=North Ryde Skyline|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/nsw_northryde.htm|website=Australian Drive-Ins|publisher=Drive-ins Downunder|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref> Until recently the Greater Union [[Blacktown, New South Wales|Blacktown]] Drive In was one of Sydney's last remaining drive-ins,<ref name="Blacktown">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/nsw_blacktown.htm|title=Blacktown Skyline|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> however a new seasonal facility with a blow up screen has recently started at Randwick Racecourse. Caringbah drive-in is now a shopping mall. A few small community drive-ins remain in rural NSW. * Greater Union Blacktown Drive-In (2 Screens), [[Blacktown, New South Wales|Blacktown]] :Blacktown Skyline was opened in the 1960s. It was the first of the Consolidated circuit to add a second screen in 1984 and has a capacity of 700 cars.<ref name="Blacktown"/> It is currently operated by [[Greater Union]]. * Heddon Greta Skyline (1 Screen), Heddon Greta The Drive in was opened in the 1960's but between 1984 - 1996 the theatre was closed, however it has been reopened. The theatre has the capacity of 676 cars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/nsw_heddongreta.htm|title=Drive-ins Downunder - Australian Drive-ins|last=Downunder|first=Yalcin Yilmaz, Catapult Design House; for Drive-ins|website=www.drive-insdownunder.com.au|access-date=2017-11-11}}</ref> It is currently operated by Skyline (Greater Union/Hoyts) and Donna and Scott Seddon.
===Queensland===
Queensland had at one stage over fifty drive-ins. Now all of the suburban Brisbane drive-in theatres have closed leaving the Tivoli Drive-In in Ipswich, and the Gold Coast's Yatala as the closest drive-in theatres to Brisbane. In rural Queensland however, there are still a number of drive-in theatres operating. [[File:Qap768-43-1958-Cropped.Inc-Cont..jpg|thumb|Boondall Drive-In, May 1958]] Brisbane's first drive-in was the Capalaba which opened in 1955. The Boondall Drive-in opened on 8 February 1956, at the time it had the largest screen in Australia. Kids were well catered for with a Merry-Go-Round, miniature Cobb & Co coach and Shetland Ponies to ride (Brisbane Telegraph, 6 Feb 1956). The site of the Boondall Drive-In has now been developed into housing.
The [[Burleigh Heads, Queensland|Burleigh Heads]] Drive-in was one of Queensland's first drive-ins when it opened in 1957 with a 500 car capacity. It was followed by the Starlight drive-in at [[Aspley, Queensland|Aspley]], which was opened in January 1957 (at a cost of £100,000). Fourth to open, in April 1957, was Hoyts Skyline Drive-in located at [[Coopers Plains, Queensland|Coopers Plains]] at a cost of £200,000. It could hold 650 cars on its 17 acres and also had a children's railway line, [[Miniature golf|putt putt]], [[badminton]] facilities and a dance floor.
The Starline Drive-In opened near Ipswich in the early 1960s. Other drive-ins opened in and around Brisbane in the late 1960s, early 1970s. These included the Keperra, the Western at Oxley, the Galaxy at Cannon Hill and the Redcliffe Drive-In on the city's northern outskirts.
In 2002 a small boutique drive-in was opened in Wonga (north of [[Gympie]]), with a second screen added in 2004, increasing it to a 250 car capacity. A third screen was subsequently added; however in January 2010 the drive-in closed, when its owner went into receivership.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gympietimes.com.au/story/2010/01/28/drive-ins-gates-close//|title=Wonga Drive-in's gates close|publisher=[[The Gympie Times]]|date=28 January 2010|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url= http://www.gympietimes.com.au/story/2010/02/03/wonga-drive-in-a-going-concern/|title=Wonga drive-in a going concern|publisher=[[The Gympie Times]]|date=3 February 2010|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> In September 2010 a new owner took over the operation of the drive-in reopening in December that year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gympietimes.com.au/story/2010/09/25/back-to-the-drive-in-future-movies-roll-at-wonga//|title=Back to the drive-in future|publisher=[[The Gympie Times]]|last=Morrissey|first=Carly|date=25 September 2010|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> The drive-in has recently closed. * Ayr Stardust Drive In, [[Ayr, Queensland|Ayr]] :The Stardust drive-in was opened in September 1964, with a capacity of 360 cars.<ref name="Mareeba"/> Built within the grounds is a hardtop cinema, so patrons can choose between outdoor and indoor movies. [[File:Yatala Drive-In 2013.JPG|thumb|250px|Yatala Drive-In during a themed event in 2013]] * Yatala 3 Drive-In (3 screens), [[Yatala, Queensland|Yatala]] :The Yatala Drive-In is the [[City of Gold Coast|Gold Coast]]'s last open-air drive-in theatre (in an area which formerly had over 20 drive-in theatres), formerly Beenleigh Drive-In, it opened on 27 October 1974, and in 2000 the theatre was renamed Yatala Twin Drive-In when a second screen was added. A third screen was added in 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://quest.newspaperdirect.com/epaper/viewer.aspx | title = Triple treat at drive-in}}</ref> * Charters Towers Tors Drive-In, [[Charters Towers, Queensland|Charters Towers]] :The Charters Towers Tors drive-in was opened in 1966 and has two screens with capacity for 300 cars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/qld_charterstowers.htm|title=Charters Towers Tors|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> * Jericho Drive in, [[Jericho, Queensland|Jericho]] :The Jericho drive-in is the smallest public drive-in located in Australia, and possibly the world, with a capacity for 36 cars. It was opened in 1969. Movies are screened once a month.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/qld_jericho.htm|title=Jericho|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> * Rodeo Drive In Mareeba, [[Mareeba, Queensland|Mareeba]] :The Mareeba Rodeo drive-in was built by Far Northern Theatres in the 1960s.<ref name="Mareeba">{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/qld_ayr.htm|title=Ayr Stardust|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> Far Northern Theatres had a circuit that extended right through far northern Queensland and into [[Papua New Guinea]]. The circuit was sold to [[Greater Union|Birch Carrol & Coyle]] in the 1970s.<ref name="Mareeba"/> In the mid-1980s, Birch Carrol & Coyle pulled out and the Rodeo was sold to Norm Janke. Janke operated the drive-in until 1998 when it closed.<ref name="Mareeba"/> It subsequently re-opened in 2002, with a 300 car capacity.
===Western Australia=== The first conventional drive-in located in Western Australia was the Highway, opened in the Perth suburb of [[Bentley, Western Australia|Bentley]] in October 1955.<ref name="Drive-in WA"/><ref>Banks, Ron.(1987) ''Brief history of drive-in theatres'' Western mail, 19 Sept 1987, p. 38,</ref><ref>Bowley, Michelle(1988) ''Drive-in theatres in WA''.Media information - Australia, Feb 1988, p. 12-16,</ref> With a 642 car capacity,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wwwmcc.murdoch.edu.au/ReadingRoom/film/image/Honniball.html|title=Cinemas 1896-1985 |publisher=[[Murdoch University]]|last=Honniball|first=Jack|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> this started a boom in suburban drive-ins which saw a further eight operating by the end of the decade (the Skyline in [[Floreat, Western Australia|Floreat]] in November 1955, Mott's in [[Gosnells, Western Australia|Gosnells]] in January 1956, the Panorama in [[Roleystone, Western Australia|Roleystone]] in March 1956, the Metro in [[Innaloo, Western Australia|Innaloo]], the Lakeway in [[Swanbourne, Western Australia|Swanbourne]] in April 1957, the Melway in [[Melville, Western Australia|Melville]], the Wirrina in [[Morley, Western Australia|Morley]] in March 1959 and the Eastway in [[Belmont, Western Australia|Belmont]] in July 1959), with another nine sites opening in the 1960s (including the Starline in [[Hilton, Western Australia|Hilton]]). The growth of Perth's suburban drive-ins then slowed to only five more built during the 1970s with the last drive-in theatre, Aceway, in the suburb of [[Morley, Western Australia|Morley]], constructed in 1980.<ref name="Drive-in WA"/><ref>Yelland, R. A. (1976) Drive-ins collection, 1933-1976 [manuscript].[[Battye Library]], MN 1941, Papers of R.A. Yelland, ACC 5531A. Sound engineer and theatre circuit manager. Records from Consolidated Theatres Pty Ltd and related organisations in the film exhibition industry, especially drive-in cinemas in Western Australia. The records include items from Consolidated Theatres, Greater X-Tone Amusements, National Theatre Supply Company, Metropolitan Cinemas, West Australian Motion Pictures Exhibitors Association, Great Northern, City, Twin City, Carnarvon, Pingelly, Carnamah and Laverton Drive-ins.</ref>
In the country areas, the first to open was the Oasis in [[Geraldton, Western Australia|Geraldton]] in 1957, and there were only three more built in the 1950s; the Mayfair in [[Bunbury, Western Australia|Bunbury]], the Avonway in [[Northam, Western Australia|Northam]] and the Morcady in [[Wongan Hills, Western Australia|Wongan Hills]]. The boom years in the country were the sixties, which saw 61 drive-ins opened, with growth then slowing to only six more built in the seventies and one in the eighties.<ref name="Drive-in WA"/><ref>''Perth's drive-in theatres closing due to competition from videos'' [[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|Daily news]], 15 July 1988, p. 14,</ref>
By the 1990s there were only three suburban drive-ins that remained, but then the Metro (a twin screen site as of 1984) in Innaloo closed in 1993 followed by the Highway (a twin screen site as of 1986) in Bentley which closed in 1994; only the Galaxy (established 1973) in [[Kingsley, Western Australia|Kingsley]] remains open within the Perth surrounds.<ref name="Drive-in WA"/> There are however a few drive-in theatres and car-friendly outdoor cinemas still operating in rural [[Western Australia]]. The [[Dongara, Western Australia|Dongara]] Drive-in, built in 1966 and opened in January 1967, has been in continual operation since this time. After a storm in 2008 the screen was replaced and the original projector upgraded. In 2015 the projector was upgraded to digital. The drive-in can accommodate 200 cars, whilst it only operates in summer it is the longest continually running drive-in in Western Australia. The [[Koorda, Western Australia|Koorda]] Community Drive-in opened in October 1965; it closed in 1983 but reopened in 1987. It has a capacity of 110 cars, has been updated to digital, and screens monthly.
===South Australia=== The Blue-Line drive-in located in [[West Beach, South Australia|West Beach]], [[Adelaide]] was the first drive-in located in South Australia,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.slsa.sa.gov.au/exhibitions/boland/AustTLvertical.htm|title=As society changes, newspapers reflect the attitudes of the times|work=Events in the News|publisher=[[State Library of South Australia]]|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref> and the first to be constructed outside of Melbourne.<ref name="Drive-in SA">{{Cite web|url=http://www.samemory.sa.gov.au/site/page.cfm?u=1292|title=Drive-In Theatres|publisher=State Library of South Australia|work=SA Memory|date=22 January 2007|last=Talbot|first=Michael|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> It was opened on 28 December 1954, it was followed by the Mainline Drive-In theatre at [[Gepps Cross, South Australia|Gepps Cross]] on 7 October 1955, which was Australia's first drive-in / walk-in theatre (with a capacity for 500 cars and seating for 400 patrons).<ref name="Drive-in SA"/> It was followed by the Shandon in [[Seaton, South Australia|Seaton]] in early July 1956, the Hi-Line in [[Panorama, South Australia|Panorama]] in March 1957, and the MGM Metro at [[Marion, South Australia|Marion]] in June 1957.<ref name="Drive-in SA"/> The first country drive-in opened at [[Port Pirie, South Australia|Port Pirie]] in September 1957.<ref name="Drive-in SA"/>
Following the closure of the Valleyline at [[Modbury, South Australia|Modbury]] in May 2003 left only the [[Wallis Cinemas|Wallis]] Mainline Drive-in at Gepps Cross as the only remaining drive-in located in metropolitan Adelaide.<ref name="Drive-in SA"/> In the country areas, the closing of Riverview at [[Murray Bridge, South Australia|Murray Bridge]] in February 2005 (after 46 years)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/sa_murraybridge.htm|title=Murray Bridge Riverview|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> and the Riverland in [[Barmera, South Australia|Barmera]] in September 2008,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.drive-insdownunder.com.au/australian/sa_barmera.htm|title=Barmera Riverland/Boneyline|publisher=Drive-ins downunder|year=1999|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> only the community run facility at Coober Pedy, the Coober Pedy Open Air Outback Cinema, remains.<ref name="Drive-in SA"/>
Over the years, the list of drive-in's in metropolitan Adelaide included:<ref name="Drive-in SA"/>
* Ocean Line Drive-In Theatre - Dyson Rd, [[Christies Beach, South Australia|Christies Beach]] * Star Line Drive In Elizabeth - Main North Rd, [[Hillbank, South Australia|Hillbank]] * Mainline Drive-In Theatre - Gawler Rd, [[Gepps Cross, South Australia|Gepps Cross]] * Star Line Drive In Gilles Plains - Blacks Rd, [[Gilles Plains, South Australia|Gilles Plains]] * Star Line Drive In Hectorville - Glenburn Rd, [[Hectorville, South Australia|Hectorville]] * Metro Drive-In Theatre Marion - Oaklands Rd, [[Marion, South Australia|Marion]] * Park Line Drive-In Theatre - Marion Rd, [[Mitchell Park, South Australia|Mitchell Park]] * Valley Line Drive-In Theatre - Tolley Rd, [[Modbury, South Australia|Modbury]] * Star Line Drive In O'Halloran Hill - Majors Rd, [[Darlington, South Australia|Darlington]] * Harbour Line Drive-In Theatre - Victoria Rd, [[Osborne, South Australia|Osborne]] * Hi-Line Drive-In Theatre - Goodwood Rd, [[Panorama, South Australia|Panorama]] * Hollywood Drive-In Theatre - Winzor St, [[Salisbury Downs, South Australia|Salisbury Downs]] * Star Line Drive In Seaton - Tapleys Hill Rd, [[Seaton, South Australia|Seaton]] * Blue Line Drive In Theatres - Military Rd, [[West Beach, South Australia|West Beach]] * Star Line Drive In Woodville North - Grand Junction Rd, [[Mansfield Park, South Australia|Mansfield Park]]
===Northern Territory=== Darwin was home to the Paspalis ([[Nightcliff, Northern Territory|Nightcliff]]) Drive-in Theatre, the largest privately owned drive-in located in Australia, which was opened in 1965 and closed in 1985. The Alice Springs Star line Drive-in operated from 1975 to 1990 closing when The Alice Springs Cinema opened in 1989. * None still open,<ref name="Aus Theatre">{{Cite web|url=http://www.theatres.com.au/|title=Theatres|work=Australian Theatres Directory|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> although [[Darwin, Australia|Darwin's]] Deckchair Cinema provides seats in an outdoor setting.
===Tasmania=== Tasmania previously had drive-in theatres at [[Glenorchy, Tasmania|Glenorchy]] and [[Warrane, Tasmania|Warrane]] in [[Hobart, Tasmania|Hobart]], and in [[Launceston, Tasmania|Launceston]], [[Devonport, Tasmania|Devonport]] and [[Burnie, Tasmania|Burnie]]. The last of Tasmania's drive-in theatres at [[Elwick, Tasmania|Elwick]] and [[Mowbray, Tasmania|Mowbray]] closed in March 1985.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/0/D3C71E9DB30DE7ACCA256C3200241897?opendocument |title=1950s-1980s, Post-war Tasmania |publisher=[[Australian Bureau of Statistics]]|work=1384.6 - Statistics - Tasmania, 2005 |date=13 September 2002 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> * None still open<ref name="Aus Theatre"/>
===Australian Capital Territory=== [[File:Former Starlight drive-in theatre sign in Watson (1).jpg|thumb|upright|right|Former Starlight drive-in sign, first neon sign in Canberra and the only drive-in sign in Australia that is still in its original location.<ref>{{cite web|title=Heritage (Decision about Registration for the Starlight Drive-In Theatre Sign, Watson) Notice 2012|url=http://www.legislation.act.gov.au/ni/2012-95/current/pdf/2012-95.pdf|work=ACT Heritage Council|publisher=Australian Capital Territory Government|accessdate=29 March 2012|date=23 February 2012}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>]] The ACT had two drive-in theatres, the Starlight in [[Watson, Australian Capital Territory|Watson]] (opened in January 1957 and closed in 1993), which has now been redeveloped for [[medium-density housing]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://issuu.com/citynews/docs/101007_citynews |title=Canberra CityNews |date=7 October 2010|page=15|last=Harris|first=Eleri|accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> and the Sundown at [[Narrabundah, Australian Capital Territory|Narrabundah]] (opened in 1968 and closed in 1984),<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/house/committee/reports/1988/1988_PP409.pdf |title=Report on the Canberra Leashold System |publisher=House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure |format=pdf |page=36 |date=November 1988 |accessdate=14 January 2011 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> which is now a [[motel]] and private housing village.
The ACT has a one drive-in theatre Southern Cross Drive-In, open on the 2 February 2018. * [[Www.driveinmovies.com.au|Southern Cross Drive-In]]<ref name="Aus Theatre" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Use British English|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox book | | name = Marabou Stork Nightmares | orig title = | translator = | image = image:MarabouStorkNightmares.jpg | caption = First edition (UK) | author = [[Irvine Welsh]] | cover_artist = | country = Scotland | language = English, [[Scots language|Scots]] | series = | genre = | publisher = [[Jonathan Cape]] (UK)
[[W. W. Norton]] (US) | release_date = 1995 (UK), 1996 (US) | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|hard]] & [[paperback]]) | pages = 264 pp | isbn = 0-393-31563-0 | oclc = 36429347 | preceded_by = [[Trainspotting (novel)]] | followed_by = [[Filth (novel)]] }} '''''Marabou Stork Nightmares''''' is an experimental novel by [[Irvine Welsh]], and his second novel. The book's narrative is split into two styles: a conventional [[first person narrative|first person]] account of the past and a more [[Surrealism|surreal]], [[Stream of consciousness writing|stream of consciousness]] account of an otherworldly present. Like many of Welsh's novels, it is written in [[Edinburgh]] [[Scots Language|Scots]] [[dialect]]. The plot consists of the memories and hallucinations of the protagonist, Roy Strang, making him an extreme example of an [[unreliable narrator]]. ==Plot summary== Roy Strang narrates the book from an (at first) unexplained coma, which he has been in for the previous two years. His life in this state is a miserable affair, surrounded by uncaring doctors and his extremely dysfunctional family. In his fantasy life, he is an adventurer in the wilds of South Africa, where he and his loyal guide, Sandy Jamieson, hunt for the [[marabou stork]]. When not hallucinating, Strang tells his life story, beginning in a "scheme" ([[Council house|local authority housing]]) in [[Muirhouse]], Scotland, with his violent, delusional parents, two half-brothers (one a womanizer, the other flamboyantly gay), and his promiscuous sister, all of whom he despises. The family relocates to apartheid-era South Africa when he is an adolescent, where he is repeatedly molested by his uncle. When his father is jailed for the violent assault of a taxi driver, the Strangs are forced to return to Scotland, a mere 18 months after they left. Strang grows into a violent, misogynistic thug. He maintains a full-time job in as a systems analyst for the fictional investment group, 'Scottish Spinsters' (a reference to [[Scottish Widows]]). He joins a gang of [[football hooliganism|football hooligans]] who are attached to [[Hibernian F.C.]], the [[Capital City Service]], and led by the fearsome Lexo. Strang enjoys his life as a "top boy," feared by the entire town, until the gang kidnaps a young woman who rejected their advances and gang rapes her; Strang informs the reader that he is horrified, but too intimidated to try and stop them, and he even joins in. The gang evades prison, but Strang is stricken with guilt and withdraws completely into depression. He briefly revives a few months later when he meets a woman and genuinely feels love for the first time. Around the same time he begins to take [[Ecstasy (drug)|ecstasy]], and even befriends his gay half-brother. The memory of what he has done continues to haunt him, and his depression soon completely engulfs him, taking him away from his lover and his drug-driven escapism. He attempts suicide but survives, putting him in a coma. One day, the gang's rape victim visits him in the hospital. She tells him that she has been murdering her rapists one by one, and now she has come for him, revealing that he was by far the most brutal and that he has been trying to convince himself and the audience (the reader) of his moral cleanliness compared that of those around him. She then penectomises him and stabs him to death. In his final moments, Strang realizes that the only person he has ever really hated is himself, and makes peace with everyone he has wronged and who has wronged him. The novel's other, more stream-of-consciousness narrative, intertwined with the story of Strang's past, takes place in the fantasy world he creates for himself in the coma. At first a bizarre but rousing adventure, it gradually becomes darker as Strang reveals the uglier parts of his life and personality, involving surreal images of brutality and sexual violence. ==Reception== Boyd Tonkin at ''[[The Observer]]'' praises Welsh for the power of his fiction and writes: "Here was a voice, out of Edinburgh by way of Hades, that would never have a problem with energy, wit or compassion. Finding the right form for all this incendiary talent might prove trickier." Tonkin suggests that Welsh does not know what to do with his fatalism, but that the story "gives a shockingly funny shape to that impasse".{{cite news | date = 23 April 1995 | author = Boyd Tonkin | title = A wee Hades | url = https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/1995/apr/23/featuresreview.review | work = [[The Observer]] }} ==Analysis== As in many of Welsh's novels, there are many allusions to music and underground youth culture, especially [[rave culture]], [[punk rock]], comic books, and football hooliganism. There is a strong message against violence towards women from men in the book, one passage is in fact set out in a capital 'Z' which is the symbol for Zero Tolerance, a women's rights group based in Scotland. The South African narrative is written in a ''[[Boy's Own Paper|Boys' Own]]'' style. The [[antisocial personality disorder|sociopath]]ic Francis Begbie, one of the main characters in ''[[Trainspotting (novel)|Trainspotting]]'', makes a [[cameo role|cameo]] appearance. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Irvine Welsh}} [[Category:1995 British novels]] [[Category:Novels by Irvine Welsh]] [[Category:Fiction with unreliable narrators]] [[Category:Novels set in Edinburgh]] [[Category:Jonathan Cape books]] [[Category:Gang rape in fiction]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} [[File:Reinhardtseminar071011.jpg|thumb|right|Reinhardt Seminar in Palais Cumberland]] The '''Max Reinhardt Seminar (Reinhardt Seminar)''' is the School of Drama at the [[University of Music and Performing Arts, Vienna|University of Music and Performing Arts]] in [[Vienna, Austria]]. It is located in the Palais Cumberland, Penzingerstraße 9, in Vienna's 14th district (<small>{{coord|48|11|21|N|16|18|44|E|type:landmark_region:AT|display=inline,title}}</small>)
== History == A ''Lehrgang für Declamation und Mimik'' (Course in Declamation and Mimics) had been in existence in Vienna since 1852, when [[Max Reinhardt (theatre director)|Max Reinhardt]] received a call to the University of Music and Performing Arts in 1929 to create a drama seminar. Initially, this Seminar was taught at the [[Schlosstheater Schönbrunn]], the imperial theatre in the [[Schönbrunn Palace]]. After Reinhardt's emigration in 1937, the seminar moved to the nearby Palais Cumberland in 1940. From 1948 until 1954, [[Helene Thimig]] (Max Reinhardt's widow) directed the Seminar.
== Curriculum == The Seminar offers a four-year course taught by some 40 professors, many of whom are themselves notable actors and directors, e.g. [[Karlheinz Hackl]], [[Heiner Müller]], [[Oleg Tabakov]], [[Giorgio Strehler]], [[István Szabó]], [[Klaus Maria Brandauer]]). After the second semester, the students specialize into various branches of acting and directing. Student performances are staged at the ''Schlosstheater''.
==Alumni== Famous past students include noted actors and filmmakers: [[Alfred Abel]], [[Peter Alexander (Austrian actor and singer)|Peter Alexander]], [[David Bennent]], [[Senta Berger]], [[Marlene Dietrich]], [[Martin Esslin]], [[O. W. Fischer]], [[Gustav Froehlich]], [[Karlheinz Hackl]], [[Monica Bleibtreu]], [[Paul Henreid]], [[Christiane Hörbiger]], [[Kurt Kasznar]], [[Hedy Lamarr]], [[Francis Lederer]], [[Ute Lemper]], [[F.W. Murnau]], [[Pola Negri]], [[Hans Neuenfels]], [[Susi Nicoletti]], [[Christine Ostermayer]], [[Erika Pluhar]], [[Helmut Qualtinger]], [[Leni Riefenstahl]], [[Otto Schenk]], [[Max Schreck]], [[Walter Schmidinger]], [[Otto Tausig]], [[Nadja Tiller]], [[Conrad Veidt]], [[Christoph Waltz]], [[Gustav von Wangenheim]], [[Ilse Werner]], [[Paula Wessely]], [[Rudolf Wessely]], and [[Peter Zinner]], George Remoundos/ Γιώργος Ρεμούνδος, Lefteris Voyatzis / Λευτέρης Βογιατζής, Sarantos Zervoulakos/ Σαράντος Ζερβουλάκος, Manos Lambrakis/ Μάνος Λαμπράκης.

'''Melbourne International Games Week''' is the largest game professional and consumer communication and networking platform in [[Asia Pacific]]. It comprises a confluence of events for three areas of interest, business, consumer and industry.
Games Week 2015 had over 60,000 atendees participating in game conferences and consumer shows across the city, including Games Connect Asia Pacific,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gcap.com.au/|title=GCAP 2016|website=gcap.com.au|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref> Unite Melbourne,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://unite.unity.com/2016/melbourne|title=Unite - Unite Melbourne|last=Technologies|first=Unity|website=unite.unity.com|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref> [[PAX Australia]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.paxaustralia.com.au/|title=PAX Australia - Melbourne, VIC Nov 4-6, 2016|website=www.paxaustralia.com.au|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref> the Women in Games Lunch, Australian Game Developers’ Awards, ACMI Family Day, VR and Serious Games Festival and the Education in Games Summit.
2016's events were held in close proximity in a number of venues, including the [[Australian Centre for the Moving Image]] and the [[Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre]]. More than 65,000 people attended in 2017.<ref>http://gamesweek.melbourne/in-the-name-of-games-migw17</ref>
The 2018 programme also includes a number of new events, including the first Melbourne Queer Games Festival focusing on games with LGBT content, an e-sports conference, and the new High Score Conference exploring the relationship between games and music.
